channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Britain Votes to Leave E.U.; Cameron Plans to Step Down
item.media:description: Supporters of the campaign to leave, one draped in Britain’s Union Jack, in central London on Friday.
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.description: The British pound and stock prices in Asia plummeted, there was immediate pressure for another referendum on Scottish independence, and David Cameron said he would resign by October.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Turbulence and Uncertainty for the Market After ‘Brexit’
item.media:description: Traders from BGC, a global brokerage in London’s Canary Wharf financial center, during trading on Friday after Britain voted to leave the European Union.
item.description: Britain’s vote to leave the Europe Union kicks off a fraught and unpredictable process likely to spook investors around the world.
item.dc:creator: PETER S. GOODMAN

item.title: ‘Brexit’ Opens Uncertain Chapter in Britain’s Storied History
item.media:description: Supporters of the Leave campaign watched the results of Thursday’s referendum in central London.
item.media:credit: Stefan Rousseau/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.description: After choosing to leave the European Union, Britain confronts the need to define a new role on the world stage even as it heals deep wounds at home.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: E.U. Referendum: Britain Votes to Leave
item.description: Britain has voted to leave the European Union, and Prime Minister David Cameron said he would resign by October. Follow along for updates and analysis.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Facebook Envy Lures Egyptian Teenagers to Europe and the Migrant Life
item.media:description: Ehab Nasser, 21, a fisherman from Burg Migheizil, Egypt, smuggled himself into Greece two years ago. The trip ended in a Greek detention center and deportation back to Egypt, but he said he would try again soon.
item.media:credit: David Degner for The New York Times
item.description: Egypt does not suffer from war or grinding poverty, but lack of opportunity, permissive Italian laws and the examples of other Egyptian teenagers have led to a surge in migration.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Mahmoud Abbas Claims Rabbis Urged Israel to Poison Palestinians’ Water
item.media:description: President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority delivering a speech on Thursday to the European Parliament in Brussels.
item.description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel denounced the Palestinian leader’s unsubstantiated allegation, saying he was spreading a “blood libel.”
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: Boeing Offers Details on Iran Deal, Saying All Was Done Legally
item.media:description: An Iran Air jet in Tehran in February. The airline, Iran’s national carrier, intends to buy 80 Boeing passenger planes.
item.description: The company was responding to a June 16 letter from congressional critics of any deal that would furnish aircraft to Iran.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Populist Anger Upends Politics on Both Sides of the Atlantic
item.media:description: Outside the Houses of Parliament in London on Friday.
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: Britain’s vote to leave the European Union brings into focus the power of disaffected voters to force change on a reluctant establishment.
item.dc:creator: JIM YARDLEY

item.title: Text of David Cameron’s Speech After ‘Brexit’ Vote
item.description: The full statement delivered by Prime Minister David Cameron after British voters in a referendum elected to leave the European Union.

item.title: Tornado Kills at Least 98 in Eastern China
item.description: An unusually strong storm in Yancheng, a city of 7.1 million overlooking the Yellow Sea, featured wind gusts exceeding 80 miles an hour by some accounts.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ

item.title: Black Boxes From EgyptAir Jet Are Going to France for Repair
item.description: If they can be restored, the black boxes found among the Airbus’s wreckage last week could help determine if the plane crash was the result of terrorism.
item.dc:creator: NOUR YOUSSEF

item.title: ‘Catastrophic’ Conditions Reported in Camp for People Fleeing Boko Haram
item.description: Doctors Without Borders said nearly 200 people died of malnutrition and illness since May 23 in northeastern Nigeria. Boko Haram attacks have displaced millions.
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE and DIONNE SEARCEY

item.title: Sinosphere: Diplomat’s Death Reignites Debate Over China’s Role in the World
item.media:description: Wu Jianmin, a longtime diplomat who warned against rising nationalism in China, in 2008.
item.description: In retirement, Wu Jianmin warned that the nationalism that had grown under President Xi Jinping should be kept in check.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ and YUFAN HUANG

item.title: ‘Leave’ Takes the Lead as Britain Awaits Outcome of E.U. Referendum
item.media:description: Pedestrians in London on Thursday. Strong rains in parts of the capital and southeast England complicated voting in the referendum on whether Britain should remain in the European Union.
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.description: The vote on Britain’s continued membership in the European Union sent currency traders scrambling and the pound first up and then down.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN

item.title: Who Is a Jew? Maybe Not Woman Converted by Esteemed New York Rabbi
item.media:description: Haskel Lookstein, a rabbi at the Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun, an Orthodox synagogue in Manhattan, in 2009.
item.description: An American convert engaged to an Israeli was turned down by a local rabbinical court when she tried to register for marriage.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Letter From Africa: Seeking to Define the Post-Mandela South Africa
item.media:description: Buses were set on fire and looters ransacked shops this week in the South African capital, Pretoria.
item.description: At a time of violence and political unrest, an opposition leader plays a long game against President Jacob Zuma and the African National Congress.
item.dc:creator: ALAN COWELL

item.title: Police Kill Movie Theater Assailant in Germany
item.media:description: Police officers arrived outside a movie theater complex where an armed man reportedly opened fire on Thursday in Viernheim, Germany.
item.description: An assailant entered a multiplex theater in the western town of Viernheim, but the police stormed the building and killed him, officials reported.
item.dc:creator: JACK EWING and MELISSA EDDY

item.title: Voting Again, Spain Faces Threat to Two-Party System
item.media:description: Supporters of Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy, the candidate of the conservative Popular Party, in Málaga, Spain, this week. The country will hold new elections on Sunday, the second vote in six months.
item.description: Despite cooperation in city and regional politics, parties have resisted forming coalitions after inconclusive national voting and the rise of new parties like Podemos.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Christo’s ‘Floating Piers’ to Close at Night for Repairs
item.media:description: Visitors last weekend at Christo’s “The Floating Piers,” which joins islands and the mainland on Lake Iseo, Italy. The installation runs until July 3.
item.description: The installation on Lake Iseo in Northern Italy has drawn over 350,000 visitors, wearing out the walkway’s fabric and straining local infrastructure.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: Sinosphere: China Vows to Replace ‘Poisonous’ Running Tracks at Schools
item.media:description: A sports field at a primary school in Beijing. The Ministry of Education has said running tracks will be inspected and, if found to contain toxic materials, replaced.
item.description: The tracks, made of industrial waste, have reportedly sickened thousands of children in a country already troubled by environmental hazards.
item.dc:creator: OWEN GUO

item.title: Hong Kong Lawmaker ‘Long Hair’ Is Arrested Over Donation
item.media:description: Leung Kwok-hung, center, a lawmaker, was a central figure in the pro-democracy Occupy Central protests that began in late 2014.
item.description: Regulators accused Leung Kwok-hung of concealing from the city’s legislature a payment of $32,000.
item.dc:creator: AMIE TSANG and PATRICK BOEHLER

item.title: The Interpreter: Making Sense of ‘Brexit’ in 4 Charts
item.media:description: Source: YouGov. This map based on YouGov’s online polling shows support for leaving or remaining in the European Union in 188 areas of the country.
item.description: To grasp why some Britons favor remaining in the European Union and others want to leave, you need to grasp some deep divisions within the country.
item.dc:creator: AMANDA TAUB

item.title: Rescue Flight Evacuates 2 Sick Workers From the South Pole
item.media:description: A rescue plane picking up two sick workers at the Amundsen-Scott South Pole Station, operated by the National Science Foundation.
item.media:credit: Robert Schwarz/National Science Foundation, via Associated Press
item.description: The plane took the patients to Chile, the National Science Foundation said, without giving details of their medical conditions.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTOPHER MELE and AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: What in the World: China Censors WeChat Rumors, Including the One About Robots Taking Over
item.description: Censorship there is well known, but bureaucrats are also focusing on more mundane matters, seeking to prevent rumors, fabricated news and superstitious premonitions from going viral.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ

item.title: What in the World: Will Ersatz Dollars Satisfy Cash-Starved Zimbabweans?
item.media:description: The old Zimbabwean dollar, which the government printed without restraint a decade ago.
item.description: Zimbabwe has been using the United States dollar as its currency, but those dollars have all but disappeared. Now the central bank is introducing replacement notes.
item.dc:creator: NORIMITSU ONISHI

item.title: What in the World: A New Verb in Mexico: Trumpear (From ‘to Punch’)
item.media:credit: Illustration by Alvaro Dominguez; photographs by MaraZe and Joseph Sohm/Shutterstock
item.description: Responding to remarks by Donald J. Trump, Mexicans are using satire, games, caricatures and other forms of ridicule to express anger and national pride.
item.dc:creator: ELI ROSENBERG

item.title: Shootout in Cyprus Resort Town Kills at Least 3
item.description: At least three people were killed and two were wounded in the resort town of Ayia Napa, the police said.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: It's Bad in Eritrea, but Not That Bad
item.media:description: Eritrean citizens in Switzerland protesting a recent U.N. report that accused Eritrean leaders of committing crimes against humanity.
item.description: A shrill and shoddy U.N. report about human rights abuses in Eritrea may only worsen the repression.
item.dc:creator: BRONWYN BRUTON
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: The World’s Disappearing Sand
item.description: Extracting the stuff is a $70 billion industry, but it can inflict terrible costs on the environment.
item.dc:creator: VINCE BEISER

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: R.I.P., Jo Cox. May Britain Remember Your Wisdom.
item.media:description: A wall of tributes in London on Monday for Jo Cox, a member of Britain’s Parliament who was murdered last week.
item.description: A united Europe would be a fitting legacy for a woman no longer able to influence the world in other ways.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS KRISTOF

item.title: Q. and A.: Ramadan Is Here. What Islam’s Holiest Month Is About.
item.media:description: Muslims praying Sunday in Bali, Indonesia, on the eve of Ramadan.
item.description: A professor who specializes in Islamic studies and Middle Eastern history explains the practices and meaning of Ramadan.
item.dc:creator: BRYANT ROUSSEAU

item.title: Not Forgotten: Inside The Times Archives
item.description: Since 1851, more than 200,000 people have been the subjects of obituaries in The New York Times. Join us each day this summer as we revisit many of these memorable lives.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Alissa Rubin, 2016 Pulitzer Winner, Reports From the Front Lines
item.media:description: Alissa Rubin
item.description: Ms. Rubin has spent much of her career covering Iraq, Afghanistan and the Balkans.
item.dc:creator: MIKE McPHATE

item.title: Lens Blog: Photography Pulitzer for Coverage of Refugee Crisis
item.description: The New York Times and Thomson Reuters shared the Pulitzer Prize for breaking news photography for coverage of Europe’s refugee crisis. Jessica Rinaldi of the Boston Globe won the feature photography prize for her story of a boy who endured abuse at the hands of those he trusted.
item.dc:creator: DAVID GONZALEZ and JAMES ESTRIN
